div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindlei Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is 22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

Tuesday, December 26, 1905
Financial Adviser's Note

The Financial Adviser's Note on the 1906 Budget, part of which we publish in our issue of to-day, is an ably conceived and admirably worded document, warning the public, as it does, against certain tendencies towards over- speculation which may in the future impede the development of the financial resources of the country and at the same time showing the remarkable financial progress actually made, especially in the last few years. We will deal later with the budgets of the various Ministries and State Departments. The preliminary re- marks, which we give in full, are most interest- ing reading. The recent abnormal rise of prices, speculation, cotton, the recent and popular reduction in taxation, the question of salaries and pensions, and the Daira Sanieh liquida- tion, in which the Government's share of the profits amount to over L.E. 3,000,000, are all discudded and are all well worth reading.

There are two passages in Sir Vincent Cor- bett's Note which we venture to criticise. In dealing with the question of speculation he takes, we imagine, slightly pessimistic view of the general effects of any reaction against over-speculation. We admit that unwary investors may suffer, but what proport on do those who will go to the wall bear to the wholepopulation of Egypt. In our opinion the general prosperity of the country, if affect- ed at all by their collapse, will be affected very slightly, for there is a very large majority composed of men of means, mostly natives, that has not yet begun to indulge in specula- tion to any great extent. If the natice land owners begin as a body to emulate some of our fellow citizens who speculate in the hands on incomes of 150 a year, then we admit the country will suffer; but have we reached that point yet? None the less the warning against overspeculation containes excellent adivce to all who may be bitten bu the fever, and while we differ in our estimate of the gravity of the results of over-speculation, we are ready to acknowledge that facts may yet prove us to have underrated the evil and minimised the danger. There is one other point which we should like to criticise. Sir Vincent Corbett remarks, in dealing with salaries and pensions, that "it will be no more possible to amass a fortune in the Government service in the future than in the past." Did not Government officials in Ismad's days at times achieve the impos- sible> But perhaps that period may be regard- ed as buried in oblivion, and the average offi- cial who has not made fortunes in recent days will, we hope, appreciate the Financial Advi- ser's remarks on the necessity of ameliorating the conditions of his service.

A capital defence of the Railway Adminis- tration is another feature of the report. We shall revert to this on another occassion, but for the present we need only say that the quoudam Cinderella among the Government Depart- ments is now being criticised because, having come into millions, she does not expend every piastre of them at once. The Financial Adviser points out that our energetic importers forget that there are taxpayers in whose defence the authorities must attempt to get the best value for the large sums they are now expending, and that, unlike the heroine of the fairy tale who dounf herself in the possession of all that she desired the instant she wedded the Prince, the Railway Administration has to wait for its quays to be widened, its lines to be doubled, and its warehouses to be built. Sir Vincent Corbett and his predecessors have done great things, but they have not learnt to create build- ings and public works by a stroke of the pen.

div.head: THE PHARAOH OF THE EXODUS
DISCOVERY OF HIS TOMB.
an IMPORTANT find at Thebes
div.p: (From our own Correspondent). Luxor, Sunday.

A discovery of the utmost importance has just been made by the well-known American Egyptologist, Mr. Theodore M. Davis, who has discovered in the valley of the Tombs of the Kings, the tomb of Mer-en Ptah, a pharaoh of the 19th dynasty. The tomb is beautifully painted, but no antiquities were found.

This pharaoh, who is also known as Meneptab, is thought by many to have been the pharaoh of the Exodus. His mummy was found in the tomb of Amenhotep II at Thebes. He suppressed the revolt of the Libyans, which broke out in the fifth year of his reign. His "Hymn of Triumph" is out on the back of a large stele, which is now in the Egyptian Museum at Thebes.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: Benha Bridge. Owing to the low water, the Benha swing bridge over the Nile will be closed for naviga- tion until 10th August, 1906.
Sanitary Department. . Messrs. Najib Ayyub Abela, Najib F. Mishelany and Haim Menache, physicians, and M. Aristotle A. Kaos, pharmacist, have been authorised to practise in Egypt.
Drinking the King's Health. The King has authorised Rear-Admiral King- Hall to make it known that he considers his health can he as loyally drunk in water or some non-alcoholic drink as in wine.
Egypt and Cyprus Mail Contract The contract for the weekly conveyance of mails between Egypt and Cyprus has been terminated. Until a fresh contract is made chance steamers will carry the mails.

Back from
. The troupe of Egyptian dancers and singers engaged last September to amuse the leisure hours of the Sultan of Morocco has returned. Its members only wish their stay had been longer, not so the Moorish taxpayer.

Egyptian Medical Papyri. The Berlin Museum has acquired a valuable collection of medical papyri, recently found in Egypt. They are said to include letters of Hip- pocrates, and to bear testimony to the interest with which medicine was studied under the Emperors.

Egyptian Ivory. The London quarterly ivory sales begin on January 30th and Egyptian ivory to the extent of 10 tons, 14 cwt, 1 qr 13 lb, has arrived in London for the sales, The total amount of ivory arrived up to date from all sources is over 20 tons.

Eastern Telegraph. This company announces the payment on January 15 of an interim dividend of 1 1/4 per cent on the Ordinary Stock free of income tax in respect of profits for the quarter ended September 30. The dividend was the same last year.

A L. M. & D. S. We may remind our readers that Dr. Ruffer, C. M. G., President of the Quarantine Board, is lecturing 5.30 o’clock this evening in the Parish Room, Bulkeley, on The Desert of Sinai." Mr. W. R. B. Briscoe, M. A., will take the chair.

The Cavalry, Journal. Captain G. Gillson, R.A., has been appointed subeditor for Egypt of the "Cavalry Journal," a new quarterly publication, which is intended for the circulation of information concerning cavalry matters in the British and other armies, and to bring the various branches of our mounted troops, both at home and in the Colonies, into closer touch with each other by encouraging the develepment and interchange of ideas.

"Egyptian Rubber Concessions." A usually wide-awake jobber in the Egyptian section of the Mining markets was (in London financial contemporary states) last week made the victim of an old, old hoax. Although a very experienced member, he was induced to make a market in 'Egyptian Rubber Conces- sions," and he must have been delegated to find business so brisk. The joke was well planned and executed. It was not long before the jobber found himself short of several hundred shares, the price being bid up against him, but about an hour elapsed before he came to realise that the concern had only an imaginary existence.

The Shrager Bankruptcy. On the 19th inst. at the London Bankruptcy Court, a sitting for public examination was held under the failure of Shrager Brothers merchants, trading at Lloyd’s avenue, E.C. also at Calcutta Colombo, Singapore, Alexandria, and elsewhere. The debtors’ affairs are being wound up in bankruptcy, and the failure appears to be of considerable magnitude, tbe joint account di-closing liabilities to the amount of £76,899, of which £64,518 are expected to rank, with assets which are esti- mated to realise £4,089, book debts (£58,805) being treated as unrealisable. The deficiency is accounted for to the extent of £53,955 by an estimated loss on contracts made on beb. If of Schrager Brothers, of Calcutta.—The hear- ing was adjourned.

div.head: THE ALEXANDRIA RIOT.
TRIAL AND JUDGMENT.
THE SPEECH FOR THE DEFENCE.
div.p: The Alexandria Native Court was again oc- cupied on Sunday and yesterday with the proceedings against the first batch of persons accused of participating in the recent distur- bance at Alexandria.

The accused were defended by Ali Bey As- sem, whose defence was based on the following points: The originators of the trouble were low-class Greeks and the natives were there as spectators. The mob, which was composed of dif- ferent nationalities, was not an unusual gather- ing, as the day was a Sunday and all the people were idling on that day. The natives took no part in the outrages under any circumstances, as can be seen from the fact that a small number of detectives was sufficient to arrest these 104 persons, who made no resistance after the mob was dispersed, and while the authorities were holding an enquiry into the matter at the Menshieh Caracol. Only 22 persons of different nationalities were slightly injured among the enormous crowd, but these ware not attacked by the unfortunate accused, against whom there is no evidence. Even the detectives did not declare before the Court that the accused had injured people. The witnesses for the defence spoke the truth, while no other witnesses could charge these 104 natives with committing any crime. Article 207 of the Penal Code, which the Parquet required to be taken as a base fur a verdict against the accused, was not appli- cable in the case of these men. There people gathered together in the Grand Square out of curiosity. If there had been any fanaticism the disorder could not have been suppressed with such ease by a small body of police, nor would a fire hose have been sufficient to disperse them. The detectives who arrested these 104 persons out of a crowd of 15,000 people could not identify them as the real evildoers. Public security in Alexandria has never been menaced, nor must some of the European newspapers be believed, who for their own purposes have misled their readers by stating that fanaticism was at the bottom of the outbreak. The question is very simple. Some Greeks, under the aegis of the Capitulations, fired at one another on a Sunday, when most people have nothing to do. A crowd of sight- seers gathered together, composed of men and women of every race and nation, in order to see what was going on, and the upshot was "a storm in a teacup."
The above was the gist of the speech of the counsel for the defence.

The Parquet called upon the Court to punish the accused in accordance with Article 207 of the Penal Code, and in the case of those who had previous convictions against them, in accordance with Articles 48 and 49, and the boys in accordance with Article 61 of the same code.

At 7.46 p.m. yesterday evening the Court gave its judgment on the 104 accused, acquit- ting 28, sentencing 53 to three months' im- prisonment with hard labour, 13 to six months' imprisonment with hard labour, 3 t0 be whipped with ten strokes each (these being boys), and 7 to twelve months' imprisonment with hard labour.

div.head: NEW ORGAN FOR ST. GEORGE'S
div.p: The new organ, the gift of the congregation worshipping in H.B.M.'s Garrison Church of St. George, Mustapha Pasha, in 1904-5, was dedicated to the service of Almighty God and for the use of the Church of England troops, on Friday last, at a special service, by the Rev. F. B. N. Norman-Lee, C.F. and chaplain in charge. Canon Ward read the lesson and gave a very helpful address on verse 6 of Psalm 95. Alter the service Mr. Heaton, organist of St. Mark’s, gave a recital of seven sacred pieces, showing the beautiful combination of the various stops.

The organ has a rich and full tone, and its sound was fully appreciated by the congregation. It is of tubular pneumatic action throughout, and has a double bass (Casson’s patent), which enables any one to play the pedal notes on the key-board, the lowest note only sounding. The effect of a second manual is obtained by the melodic stop, whereby the melody of a hymn or voluntary is made to stand out above the accompaniment. The entire organ has been specially constructed to suit the climate.

On Saturday last the third performance of La Tosca was given and drew, as usual, a vast and highly appreciative audience. It was an excellent representation from first to last, one calculated to cause ecstacies of rapturous emotion. Signs. Bellincioni overpowered us by her forcible and gifted acting, coupled with exquisite singing, a combination which never fails to convey the pathos which this difficult role demands. Her notes were pure and pene- trating as ever, though not quite so powerful as on the last occasion we witnessed this opera, and for this the damp weather will no doubt have been to blame. Sig. Palet, as Mario, again sang with fervour, dignity, and distinction, while Sig. Polese repeated his remarkably fine interpretation of the heavy part of Scarpia. Sig Gisnoli took great pains to give full effect to the role of the Sagrestano. The orchestra, under Sig. Zuccani, left nothing to be desired.

div.head: ’XMAS AT CAIRO.
THE WEATHER COLD.
FESTIVITIES AT THE HOTELS.
div.p: At Cairoon ’Xmas Day the usual services were held at the Protestant and Roman Ca- tholic churches, and in the evening a small dance was given at Shepheard’s, where every- thing went as merrily as the date demanded and dancing lasted till very late. The banks were dosed, the British Government officials took holiday, and the Europeans in general affected to be satisfied with the weather on the ground that 'Xmas ought to be cold.

On 'Xmas Eve an imposing ’Xmas Tree was to be seen in the Grand Continental Hotel. The little ones were delighted and the grown ups enjoyed a small dance that followed to the full. The ball-room was crowded and dancing lasted till those present could wish "a merry ’Xmas" to one another before they went home.
SHEPHEARD’S CHRISTMAS TREE.

A large and merry crowd of children with a still larger attendance of "grown-ups" collect- ed in the outer hall of Shepheard’s Hotel on Sunday afternoon to await the drawing aside of the curtains and the revelation of a magni- ficent Christmas Tree in the "Egyptian Hall.” From half-past four to half-past five the guests arrived in ever-increasing numbers, and save for the occasional protest of a few infant voices at not being allowed immediate entrance to the fairy-laud within, all were gay and happy from beginning to end. But the infants turned from teats to cries of enjoyment and babbling laughter as the curtains parted and the throng slowly pressed into the hall and surrounded the gorgeously decorated and illuminated tree, and tiny hands were stretch- ed out to the master of the ceremonies to receive a coveted ticket which would ensure a memento of this Christmas party. The presents were laid out in the billiard room, the tables of which were burdened with books and toys of every description (without even a word of protest from their guardian angel, Percy), and every little guest departed with a heart gladdened by a beautiful gift. The Tzigane orchestra played selections of music during the afternoon, and the buffets, which were abundantly furnished with teas, cakes, ices, and all sorts of good things, were well patronised. Mr. Baehler ana most generously, and his party was greatly enjoyed by the several hundreds of guests who were present.

div.head: XMAS AT MENA.
div.p: Seldom or never has the terrae of Mena House Hotel been so crowded as on the afternoon of 'Xmas Eve. It was really sur- prising when everybody is supposed to be up by the Nile, to find such a large gathering of smart people at Mena House. At 4.8 p.m. the charming dining-hall was filled with a select audience for the carol singing by the staff choir. Unfortunately, however, they were unable to complete the programme, which consisted of six items, on account of the well- deserved encores of the carol singers. These quaint old German songs were alone well worth the trip to Mena, and the zither accom- paniment and the "echo" effect of "Teure Heimat" were very good. The dining hall itself with its 'Xmas Tree and the illuminated models of the Sultan Hassan Mosque and some ancient temple produced, with the candles and electric light, quite a fairy scene.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL THEATRE, CAIRO.
CYRANO DE BERGERAC.
div.p: It is a distinct pleasure to be able to attempt a serious criticism instead of the usual resume of the play and list of the actors on to whose names are tacked "sustained the role of," "his known verve," etc. For the performance of Cyrano will quite bear criticism, even compari- son,to a certain degree, with more famous repre- sentations of the same play, in Paris. It is a play with two parts—possibly three, if we count Ragueneau, and it proved in consequence not beyond the reach of the company. Mme Moreno played Roxane, and achieved most accurately the exact "precieuse plus beauty" note: a thankless note indeed hered for it allows of very little passion or emotion: it has but affectation and a certain delicate egoism. M Daragon was Cyrano, and after the first two acts proved good; in the balcony scene, the journey to the moon, and the last act of all he was really excellent. The ballads duel in the first act was well done: but for the greater part of this and the second, he missed, or exaggerated, his chances: he suggested the schoolboy anxious to get through his Virgi repetition, or on the other hand he relied on one or two intonations to carry off all points. Now the points all through are many, subtle, various; one has only to see Coquelin to discover that. His gestures were good all through; but the “make-up," except in the last act, was not at all right; where was the nose. Scarcely in evidence, and certainly not "stalking before me, half a league ahead.” The other parts were good after their kind except . de Guiche. M. Monteux lacked dignity and restraint and was too excited for the "grand seigneur" he was supposed to represent. The staging of the "siege of Arrus" scene was not good; and the effect of the supers charging down the steps was absurd. It is some six years since we saw it in Paris, but if we remember right the supers hardly appeared at all; only their heads showed, the Gasoons' post being on an eminence above them. Well, to sum up, it might have been much worse, and even if it wasn’t “Paris," it was safely above the "provin- cial" mark.

div.head: EGYPT AND U.S.A.
NEW DIPLOMATIC AGENT.
PRESENTATION OF CREDENTIALS.
div.p: The following is the text of the speech addressed to the Khedive by the Hod. Mr. Eddings, the new'y appointed American Diplo- matic Agent at Cairo, in presenting his credentials to H. H. the Khedive, on Friday last: —

Your Highness, — I have the honour to present this letter of credence from the Presi- dent, accrediting me to the Egyptian Govern- nent as American Agent and Consul General. I am charged to renew to Your Highness the assurance of the cordial feeling of friendship and respect with which the President and the people of the United States regard this wonder- ful Egypt: and to emphasize the hope that this friendship may become even closer. It is a pleasure to me personally to act as the American representative in Cairo, and I ask, and feel sure that I shall receive, the support and encouragement of your Highness in the care which I shall give to American interests in Egypt, commercial and otherwise. Allow me to offer my best wishes for the health and happiness of Your Highness, and for the pros- perity of your country and its people.

His Highness replied as follows:— Monsieur l’Agent,—Je reçois avec un vif plaisir la lettre que vous me remettez et suis heureux des sentiments que vous venez de m'exprimer de la part du President et du peu- ple des Etats Unis. Comme vous, M. l’Agent, j’ai l’espoir que leur amitié pour mon pays deviendra plus étroite et je me plais á vous assurer de mon appui et du concours de mon gouvernement dans l‘accomplissement de la mission qui vous est confiée.

Je vous remercie oordialement des voeux que vous faites pour moi et pour l’Egypte, et vous prie, M. l'Agent, de vouloir bien transmet- tre au Président de la Grande République américaine l’expression de ma très vive grati- tude, avec l'assurance que j’ai sincèrement à coeur de répondre à Sa précieuse amitié.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE AND HIS ARMY.
div.p: The Khedive has despatched the following telegram to the Sirdar : "I have just returned from the Kiswet El Sherifeh ceremony and desire to place on record my appreciation of the admirable manner in which the parade was carried out, the appearance of the troops in general, and especially the splendid condition of the winter clothing. Pray accept my congratula- tions for yourself and the officers and men present."

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: A Council of Ministers will be held on Thursday at Abdeen Palace, under the presi- dency of H.H. the Khedive.

div.head: KUTTABS IN THE PROVINCES.
div.p: Our Akhmin Correspondent writes : - Fif- teen kuttabs will soon be ready for use in the near future for our markaz. The distribution of grants-in-aid to the fikis and arifs of the Akhmin kuttabs took place on Wednesday in the hall of the markaz, under the presidency of the Moudir of Guirgeh, Ibrahim Bey Na- breh, who came from Sohag for the purpose, accompanied by the wakil el Moudirieh, Wassif Bey, the Hakimdar, and the inspector of Ghirgeh province kuttabs.

The moudir delivered an address to the omdehs and notables on the building of kuttabs in the surrounding villages and exhorted the fikis to have a whole-hearted devo- tion to their calling. The inspector of kuttabs then gave an address, after which the grants- in-aid were distributed.

Our Minet el-Kamh Correspondent writes:— Last Monday was appointed for the distribution of the grants-in-aid to the fikis and arifs of the kuttabs in our district, which took place at 11.30 a.m. in a big tent near the markez office under the presidency of the Moudir of Charkieh and in presence of a Public Instruc- tion inspector and the notables of the district. The moudir spoke for about half an hour and thanked the notables of the Charkieh province for their generosity. The inspector of kuttabs, the Omdeh of Bakkashin, and a clever fiki made excellent speeches on the benefits of kuttabs. The grants-in-aid were then given by the moudir to the fikis, who were very g’ad to receive them.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES.
11TH MEETING OF SHAREHOLDERS
AFFAIR SENT BEFORE TRIBUNALS.
div.p: At 3.30 p.m. on Saturday the eleventh meeting of the creditors of the Société de- Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypte took place at the Commercial Chamber of the Mixed Tribunals Cairo, under the presidency of Judge Tuck. Me. Carton de Wiart, whose lameness prevented him from rising, was grant- ed permission to speak sitting, and opened the ball with a plea for a farther postponement. He stated that the proposals made under the concordat had been sent to Paris and that a wire had been received from Paris begging for a postponement of their publication till the 19th inst. Since then certain modifications had been insisted on by the shareholders, and matters were not yet finally settled. This being so, he begged for a week's postponement, and expressed the hope that the juge-commis- would be induced, in deference to the wishes of the whole body of creditors, to withdraw from his determination already expressed to send the affair before the Tribunals.

Me. St. Plancat and Me. Bakri, representing Me. Padoa Bey, joined in the demand, but Judge Tuck was inexorable as Rhadamanthus. He remarked that the cessation of payments took place on September 7. The judgment authorising the application of the concordat préventif was given on September 19. The first meeting of creditors took place on October 4, when the first report of the experts was read. The Sucreries asked for a postponement on account of the shareholders’ meeting. The next meeting accordingly took place on October 18, and since then matters had made no progress, in spite of eleven meetings. Conse- quently he saw no alternative but to send the case before the Tribunal on Saturday next.

The avocats protested in vain. "You will bring your proposals before the Tribunal,” quoth the judge, “far more rapidly. Here we have nothing but requests for new postpone- ments and promises for the next time, but I have not had any communication of the pro- posals made to me." Me. Carton de Wiart remarked that the proposals had been sent to Paris. Judge Tuck observed that they had not been made before him. Me. St. Plancat then asked whether the proposals might be discussed before the Tribunal. An emphatic negative from Judge Tuck, who pointed out that the Tribunal simply had to decide whether the company was to be ad- mitted to the privileges of the concordat pre- ventif. For his part he would not keep the responsibility of the affair on his shoulders for 48 hours.
The greffier, M. Zigliara, then read the following note from the experts, Sir W. Will- cocks, Fourneron Bey, and Prof. Sampaolo :-
Monsieur le Juge Commis,
Nous avons l'honneur de vous informer que nons avons fait notre estimation du bilan dec Sucreries en admettant qu'avant la fin de novembre l'avenir de cette Société serait défini- tivement résolu.
Les renvois successifs demandés font que nous sommes á fin décembre et qu'auoune dé- cision n'a été prise.

Nous considéron que la culture de la canne pour l'exercice 1906 1907 est déja compromise. car les cultivateurs ne peuvent pas faire des arrangements pour les cultures de l'anuée pro- chaine, sans ê re certains que lears productions seront schetées.
Nous vous avons d'ailleurs monsieur le juge commis, mis an courant de cerre situation dans notre première entrevue en octobre dernier.

Nous croyons donc devoir vous informer que notre estimation des usines, matériel et pièces de rechange, etc. a été fixée pensant qu'une décision définitive serait prise immédiatement après le dépôt de notre troisième rapport; mais industriellement parlant ces prix devraient déjà être diminués et si cette décision devait encore tarder, la valeur industrielle des usines, etc. deviendrait fort deuteuse, à moins que MM. les controleurs et administrateurs, ayant pris en considération l’avis que nous avons donné le 23 novembre, aient déjà traité avec les propriétaires de la Hante-Egypte afin d’as- surer aux usines de la Société la canne néces- saire et en quantité sufficante pour une période- de 4 années.

div.head: PICTURE EXHIBITION.
div.p: On Saturday last M. Warton Mahokian open- ed the exhibition of his paintings at the Immeu- ble Bitter in Opera-square, Cairo, and though the weather was bitterly cold and rain fell occasionally, quite a number of people visited the rooms, where there were over a hundred oil paintings on view. Though all of these were not to our taste, they were all well painted, and it was evident that the work had been done by a real artist. Seascapes were the principal fea- tures of the exhibition and the painting of sea scenes certainly seem to be M. Mahokian’s forte, whilst of his landscape his winter scenes were the best. Of these latter, two were espe- cially effective and realistic, a winter’s evening in Russia and a similar scene in the environs of Berlin (Nos. 84 and 71), and of other land- scapes a picture of a brigands’ resting place in the Caucasus (No. 47) was remarkable for its boldness and excellent colour effects; there was also a very fine painting of a woodland scene (No. 11) in which the colouring was very true to nature. Among the seascapes there were several fine sunsets, notably on the Jutland shores (No. 24) and on the Swedish shores (No. 94), and some splendid paintings of stormy seas. We certainly recommend our read- ers to pay this excellent exhibition a visit.

div.head: FOOTBALL
div.p: On Friday, 15th inst., a football match was played between Boulac Railway Institute and the R.E. The home team won the toss and de- fended Embabeh end. There were considerably more than 150 spectators on the club veran- dah. The play during the first half was of a very even character and neither side scored. Twenty minutes after the restarting the R.E. had the good fortune of being awarded a penalty kick, from which they scored. The visitors added another goal before the game was over, and thus were left victors by 2-0. A heavy wind, which at periods amounted to a gale, blew during the second half, and greatly hindered accurate football.

div.head: BATTLE AT MOSCOW.
BARRICADES BOMBARDED.
SEVERE FIGHTING.
5,000 KILLED, 14,000 WOUNDED.
div.p: St. Petersburg, December 23. The whole strength of the strike is centred at Moscow, at which city the Government is strenuously fighting against it. The represent- atives of strikers, while dismissing their final plans in a large building yesterday evening, were summoned to surrender. They replied with bombs and revolvers, upon which the artillery shelled the building until they capi- tulated. Barricades have been erected, but the troops have stormed several them.
Moscow, December 23. Severe fighting has taken place between the dragoons and the strikers. Barricades have been destroyed. 40 strikers, 5 officers, and 13 soldiers have bean killed or wounded. (H.)

Moscow, December 24.. A regular pitched battle is engaged in in the streets here. Yesterday afternoon there was incessant firing in all quarters of the city, which was still progressing at ten o’clock in the evening. It is impossible to estimate the num- ber of casualties.

Apparently the revolutionary party is not yet crushed. Guns posted in a commanding position at a monastery and in a square in the heart of the city opened a hot fire on the barricades during the afternoon, while quick firers swept the boulevards which debouch on the square. Fire was concentrated on the barricades on Tverskykastreet, destroying them. Meanwhile a large force of infantry kept up an incessant rifle fire, and sharpshooters posted in the belfry of the monastery picked off insurgents. Different parts of the town are isolated, and insurgents, who are supplied with arms and ammunition, are erecting fresh barricades, and are still holding some districts.

(5.0 p.m.) Artillery, rifle, and revolver fire continued during the whole day. The guns bombarded barricade after barricade, charges of dragoons followed the cannonade. The debris was then burned. The area of the fighting is extending and is now proceeding in the suburbs, with losses on both sides.

The revolutionary party is apparently not yet disheartened, though the wounded alone on Saturday are estimated at 500. They scored a few minor successes by means of ambuscades and bombs, in one case killing or wounding 20 gendarmes. All the hospitals and doctors’ resi- dences are full of wounded. (Reuter)
Moscow, December 24. The artillery have bombarded the barricades. The collisions are spreading. (Havas)
Moscow, December 25. Fighting ceased at midnight. (Reuter)
Moscow, December 25. It is believed that the number of people killed during the last few days amounts to 2,000. (Havas)

Moscow, December 26. Until an early hour on Monday morning there were 5,000 killed and 14,00 wounded in the fighting here. The cannonading was proceeding on Monday night in several parts of the city. The barricades are being desper- ately defended. Many harmless people have been killed. The city is beginning to feel the lack of provisions. (Reuter)

div.head: A LITHUANIAN INVASION
SITUATION AT ST. PETERSBURG
POPULATION ATTACKING STRIKERS
div.p: St. Petersburg, December 23. Several thousand Lithuanians have invaded the province of Vitebak, sacking and burning. Tbey declare their intention of forming a Lithuanian Republic. (Reut)

St. Petersburg, December 23. The police have arrested the executive com- mittee of the strike. The workmen’s societies of numerous railways have proclaimed a strike. The population are attacking the strikers as they are without food. Sanguinary encoun- ters have taken place in which people hare been killed or wounded. (Havas)
St. Petersburg, December 24. The city is quiet. (Havas)
Warsaw, December 25. The telegraphists have decided to end the strike. The service has been resumed. (Havas)

div.head: TO PROTECT FRENCH CITIZENS.
div.p: Paris, December 25. Two ships of war have been ordered to hold themselves in readiness to proceed to Russia to protect French citizens. (Reuter)

div.head: DATE OF DISSOLUTION.
div.p: London, December 23. The Privy Council is summoned for the 8th of January. Dissolution will follow immediately. (Reuter)

div.p: Shanghai, December 25. The Mix d Court was re-opened on Saturday. Proceedings were normal. (Reuter)

div.p: Adis Abeba, December 25. In accordance with the Emperor’s orders the engineers of the Ethiopian railways have begun the works for the continuation of the line from Diradaoua to this city. (Reuter)

div.head: THE EMANCIPATION OF EGYPT
div.p: IV. In approaching his "Ultimate considerations” our author takes us somewhat more into his confidence and says that he is addressing us in a loftier strain, and is drawn into speaking of religions beliefs. He is conscious that he is treading on tender ground. There we quite agree with him, and as we shall endeavor to show in our concluding remarks, he is doing so in a manner which is not only useless, but danger- ous. We shall therefore not make any further allusion to his concluding pages, so far as they touch religious questions ; we only quote a few paragraphs from them.

In a book referring only to Egypt it appears to us quite useless to again rake up the tragedy of American colonisation. We never heard that in these more enlightened times there was ever any risk that such proceedings were likely to occur in Egypt.

As to our author’s concluding sentence, we will merely say that we do not consider that the arguments advanced in the latter part of his book are either dictated by political lure rest, by the voice of humanity, or even by that of simple expediency.

The disjointed extracts which we have given may not convey a good idea of the book as a whole, but we think they justify us in having said that it is a remarkable book; it should be read to be appreciated, and it is Well worth reading. Up to a certain point we entirely agree with the opinions expressed by the author, then we come, almost imperceptibly, to a parting of the ways, which leads at last to extreme divergence of opinion like two lines of railway whose separation is at first almost impercepti- ble, but which end by going in nearly opposite directions. The book is written in an irreproach- able style, the arguments are all exceedingly moderate; it is with regret, and only from a sense of duty to the land we love, that we feel obliged to express some opinions contrary to those of the author. For the translator, we have nothing but praise : the book is written from end to end in flowing periods and well- balanced sentences, which contrast favorably with much of the slipshod English we have to put up with now-a-days. There is not, as is so usual in translations, any taint of foreign idiom.

To a man so well informed as the author, we cannot help thinking that it must be a matter of regret to have written the pages he devotes to Russian influence. It seems extra- ordinary to read this in a book fresh from the press in the latter end of this year of grace 1905, now that the brass giant formerly called the Holy Russian Empire has been proved to have feet of clay. It reminds us of the flood of literature, emanating any time the last forty years, from the pens of educated Russian bureaucrats, as to the objects and aims of their nation, these writings had about as intimate an acquaintance with the real nation they referred to, as the fishes in the ocean have with the first-class passengers on board a luxurious liner. Unless we are much mista- ken the near future of Russia will prove to our author that it is not wise for any nation to associate the religions element too closely with civil government, and this is the direction towards which the parting of the ways fatally leads him.

No one respects the religions element in national life more than we do, but in such a cosmopolitan country as Egypt where so many foreign colonies of different religions have from time immemorial acquired rights, which give them, in the beautiful words of Kipling, "freedom to live by no man’s leave underneath the law," this is the first con- sideration ; it is what we have now, and it is what we mean - to keep if we can.

Civil laws made and enforced for the good of the whole country should be carefully separated from the religions element, and still leave everyone perfectly free to worship God in any way which either nationality, association, or inclination may dictate, and that without interfering in any way with his rights of citizen- ship.

Our author has led up to the question of the emancipation or nationalism of Egypt in many ways. He goes back far enough to call our attention to the rise, decline, and fall of the British power in the Ionian islands ; he refers to other historical matters, all of which appear to us to have little to do with Egypt ; he devotes a whole chapter to the "false posi- tion of Great Britain in Egypt.” Without going much into detail, we do not consider this position a false one ; we think that England is still doing, and will continue to do, yeoman’s work in Egypt, not only in her own interest but to the benefit of the world in general. The most remarkable point about this book is the extraordinary metamorphosis which the au- thor’s opinion seems to us to go through within the limits of its pages. He begins by being the greatest apologist we have yet heard of. Eng- land’s occupation of Egypt; he praises it in such lofty language that at times we were tempted to recall the prophet of old, who, looking down from the barren hills of Moab, on the fertile plains and valleys on the other side of Jordan, said, almost in spite of himself, "How beautiful are thy tents, O Israel." Unlike the seer of Bible history our anthor has apparently been induced to change his opinion when about half-way through with his work.

To any intelligent person who has watched the course of events in this country for the last thirty years, it must be evident that Egypt always has required, and will still for a very long time require, some external restrain- ing influence. This has been clearly shown over and over again whenever anything has tended to ruffle the surface of everyday life.
*The emancipation of Egypt. Translated from the Italian. London, Chapman & Hall.

div.head: FREEMASONRY IN EGYPT.
div.p: The most important events among Masons each year—the installation of the W.M — were commenced on Monday week by the installation of the W.M. of the Ragheb Lodge No. 51 Egyptian Constitution, it happens to be the first of the Masonic year, and is always looked forward to.

After the lodge was opened by the W M., who was very ably assisted by Wor. Bres Felix Powell, W.M. of the Grecia Lodge Eng. Co ., Paul Oziol, W.M Union and Soldaritie Ev. Con., Foster-Smith, W.M. of the Idris Lodge Illustrious Bre. Assidourian 33. W. Bros P. Plunkett. I. P. M., W. J. King. W. H Brock- way, E. Drechsler, G. Gottlieb, T. M. Chinn, R. R. Smithard, W. Button, M. R. Pattison, R Watson-Ramsay, and Fred Phillips, and Bros. Dr. Madden, S. W. Grecia Lodge, Dr. T Burns, Klingler, Kenneth-Scott, Fitzpatrick, A. V. Thomson, Waller, Paton, Horse, Delburgo, M. A. Delburgo. Letailla, R. Spelling, D. Mac- donald, B. W. Jordan, L. Leon. I. Selighson, H. E. A. B. Brewster Bey (W. M. elect), General Mahmoud Tewfik, and many others. Bro. M. Kenneth-Scott was duly affiliated, and Mr. Howard, a candidate for initiation, was admitted and duly received his first insight into the mysteries. The following distinguished brethren were appointed to fill the various offices for the occasion, via: W. Bros. Chinn. S W., W.J. King, J W., Button, S. D. Pattison, J. D. Drechsler, I. G., and Plunkett, as D. of C.

The lodge being opened in the next degree, the W.M. elect swore allegiance to the duties of the post, and on being opened in the 3rd the M. W. the Grand Master of Egypt, his Excellency Idris bey Razheb, entered the lodge and was duly received in accordance with ancient custom and saluted as befitted his exalted rank; the gavil being banded him by the W. M., the G Master requested the W. M. to carry on the work. A board of installed Masters having been formed, the W. M. elect was further instructed and was placed in the hair of K.S. in accordance with custom. On the return of the brethren to the lodge W. Bro. Brewster Bey was proclaimed and sainted from the usual position. The charter, constitu- tions and bye-laws having been presented, W. Bro. Beale, I. M. called, the brethren to order while he read a communication he had received from the Grand Lodge, in which was a decree appointing the newly-installed W. M. as Past Grand Warden of Egypt. The M. W. Grand Master heartily congratulated Rt Wor. Brewster Bey on the appointment. The W. M. cordially thanked him for the high honor conferred upon him. The G M. then requested permis- sion to retire. The W M. was saluted with the honors due to his rank, and then appointed his officers for the year as follows:— I. P. M., Wor. Bro. Beale; S. W. Bro. W. H Latailla ; J. W., Bro. D Macdonald; Treas., W. Bro. W H. Brockway, Sec, Bro. R. Snelling; S D., Bro B W. Jordan ; J.D , W. Bro. W. Button ; D. of C.. Bro. F. Leonard; Asst ditto, Bro. Haseldine; XX I. G., Bro W Barnes, and Guardians, Bros. Canning and Yacoub. W. Bro. Ahmed Nasrat Bey organist, V Wor. Bro F. B. N. Norman-Le, chaplain, Bros L Leon and Jordan Smith, stewards.

The installation ceremony being completed, the W. M., rising, said a few words regarding the manner in which the installing Master had carried out the ceremony and expressed his pleasure in being now entitled to present the P. M. jewel unanimously voted by the lodge, and added that, although it was only a very small thing and could not adequately represent the feelings that the I.P.M. had raised in the breasts of the members of the lodge for the manner in which the duties in the lodge has been carried out, it was meant as a mark of esteem and appreciation. The L. P. M,. replying, felt proud to be a P.M. of the Ragheb Lodge and would ever do his utmost to further its interests. He said how grateful he felt to all the members for their cordial and loyal support, during his year of office, and asked that the same might be extended to his successor. He felt sure that at the close of this and following years the bond of friendship, would be found to have grown stronger and stronger.

The balance sheet showed a very substantial cash balance at the bank, and it was proposed to send a further donation to the Blind Insti- tution at Zeitoun of 1O. This was agreed to with acclamation. It was pointed out that this excellent institution received candidates irrespective of religion, nationality, or stand- ing, and that it deserved every encouragement, as it was now supported by subscriptions and contributions similar to that now put before, the meeting. The charity bag being circulat- ed produced a very handsome sum for this and similar benevolent purposes.
Before closing the lodge congratulations were conveyed to the W. M. from the lodges in Egypt and from all parts of the globe for a happy and successful year of office.

The members then adjourned to the Grand Continental Hotel, where a very handsomely decorated table testified to the great care which is given to these festivities by its genial manager, Bro. A. Klingler. The chef was called for and heartily congratulated on the manner in which the good things provided were served up.

The usual loyal and Masonic toasts were given with musical honors and heartily re- ceived the toast of the evening being that of the W.M., who, in replying, amidst storms of auplanse, signified his intention to make the lodge as great a success, if not greater than his predecessor. The manner in which this was received testified to the happiness that sur- rounded the W.M. & augors well for the future of the lodge, and the cementing of the fraternal bonds.
The following brethren helped to make the evening a very pleasant one with songs, recitations, selections, & W. Bro. Button, Powell, Bros. Dr. Madden, Waller, Barnes, Latailla, &
By kind permission of the commanding offi- cer and officers the Royal Inniskilling Fusilier- a portion of the band played selections during the banquet, which were greatly appreciated.

The M.W. Grand Master sent his excuses with regret at being unable to be present at the banquet as he had been, and is still, in the hands of his medical adviser. Hopes were expressed for a speedy return to health. He was very able represented by W. Bro. A.C Garofallo, A.G S.
[Rt. Wor. Brewster Bey was installed in the above-named lodge and not the "Idris," as notified in a Cairo contemporary. — Ed. E. G.]

div.head: THE 1906 BUDGET.
FINANCIAL ADVISERS NOTE.
EGYPT’S CONTINUED PROSPERITY.
div.p: My last Budget Note drew attention to the rapid advance in prosperity which had charac- terised the two preceding years. That prosperity has to all outward appearance been maintained.

In spite of a low Nile flood in 1904, and of the remission during the last three years of taxation, amounting in the aggregate to L.E. 490,000, the figures of revenue for those years have been as follows:—

These results have encouraged the Govern- ment to take a somewhat more sanguine view than would have been prudent hitherto of the probable results of the next financial year; these, after allowing for a further reduction to the extent of L.E. 332,000, have been calculated at L.E. 13,500,000, an estimate which can hardly be considered too bold seeing that, even when the above reduction is taken into account, it still falls short of the probable receipts for 1905 by LE. 768,000.
The estimated Receipts and Expenditure for 1906 as compared with 1905 are as follows : —
Allowing then for a surplus next year of L.E. 500,000, there remains an estimated expenditure in 1906 of L.E. 1,245,000 more than that for 1905.
This increase, though considerable, must not be taken to imply any new or extravagant departure on the part of the Egyptian Govern- ment.

The enormous appreciation in the value of land, and sudden acquisition of unexpected wealth by large sections of the community, has sent up the prices of the necessaries of life* at such a rate as to render inevitable a largely increased expenditure not only on such items as forage, maintenance of prisoners, hospital patients, and the like, but also on the wages of temporary employees and daily labourers in Go- vernment employ and consequently on the cost of execut on of all Government works. To this must be added a sum of L.E. 120,000, inscribed in the "Budget for improving the position of the “cadreé officials, the lesser of whom can no longer live on their pay, while the higher have seen, what were formerly considered adequate incomes yearly diminishing in purchasing power to the point of absolute hardship. The total increase in estimated expenditure directly attributable to the rise in prices may be calculated at not less than L.E. 370,000.
The following table shows the variations in the retail prices of certain commodities during the past five years. The figures give the average price for the year in each case: -
The rise since last year in the contract prices of provisions for certain Government Depart- ments is shown by the following examples:

Since writing the above and while this Note was passing through the press the fact that the scarcity and consequent cost of unskilled labour is becoming a factor of the gravest import in connection with the ex- penditure on all public works, has been brought to my notice with disagreeable directness. I learn from the Irrigation authorities that the cost of construction of earthworks has risen within the last three years by at least 60 % and that consequently the estimates for the conversion next year of the basin lands in Upper Egypt will probably have to be in- creased by some L.E 100,000.]
Although the revenue returns of the last few years appear amply to justify this increase in the national expenditure, nevertheless the economical situation is not such as would

*The price of some descriptions of urban land has remained proportions which can only be described as fabulous east of purelt agricultural land has increased in 5 years to at least 40% and is now selling in many places at L.E. 160 per acre and even more.

warrant us in blindly counting on permanent surpluses each as those of the past. It may well be that the wave of prosperity is not yet spent, but it would be foolhardy to calculate on its volume being increased or indeed maintained indefinitely.
In this connection the figures of imports and exports for the last six years as given by the Customs Returns deserve something more than a passing notice. They are, as follows:-

The effect of the high prices ruling for cotton from the 1902-1903 season onwards is very well marked by the increased value of the exports since 1901, and by a corres- ponding upward movement in the volume of the imports, commencing in 1903 and con- tinuing progressively to the present time. The value of the imports of merchandise for the current year bids fair largely to exceed that for 1904, as against a setback in the value of the exports due to the sensibly lower price of cotton last season.

The fact that during the past two years the imports of merchandise and specie taken together have greatly outbalanced the exports, notwithstanding the constant heavy charge for the service of the foreign debt, constitutes a phenomenon which calls for reflection. A readjustment in the direction of normal equilibrium must come about sooner or later, and if we are paying for our imports with capital provided by the foreign investor, this operation, though by no means necessarily unsound at present, cannot be indefinitely continued.

div.head: SPECULATION IN EGYPT.
div.p: Here, with a full sense of the responsibility attaching to an expression of opinion which cannot but have something of an ex cathedra character, I desire to sound a note of warning to those who look on Egypt as an El Dorado for investors- and speculators.

The sudden secession of wealth and com- mercial activity in this country has been attended by features that are only too often its concomitants. The tendency to discount the future is nowhere more evident, and during the past two years the value of property both in land and in local stocks and shares, has, in many cases, been forced up to levels which even prospective results can hardly prove to be remunerative. It is to be feared that these inflated values are not infrequently based on speculative purchases which have been facilitated by the profuse introduction of loanable capital into the country, either in the form of new banking, finance, and land companies, or in that of large increases in the capital of the old institutions. The gambling fever is rife in the community and oppor- tunities to speculate are at hard for all.

This situation contains within it the elements of reaction. It depends, first and foremost, on the maintenance of the price of cotton at the high level of the past three years, a level due to causes which are almost entirely adventitious as far as this country is concerned. And, even assuming that the conditions of the world’s supply of and demand for cotton will not vary within very wide limits for the next few years, or that the demand for the Egyptian product will continually outstrip the supply, there remains the danger of the results which invariably attend over speculation. Lately signs of uneasiness have not been wanting; there is a slackening of activity on the local Bourses and quotations have declined perceptibly from their former maxims.

A movement towards the elimination of the speculative factor in the situation, which in the long run is inevitable, may, and I believe will, work itself out without injury to the real interests of the country, but it will hardly do so without causing a considerate perturbation of the share market, with serious results to the unwary investor.

I may as well mention here that all Egyptian companies are incorporated by Khedivial Decree, and that such decree merely implies that the company in question has conformed with certain rules and is amenable to a certain jurisdiction. It in no way implies that the Khedivial Government either approves its object or guarantees its solvency.

div.head: COTTON.
div.p: The area devoted to cotton during the pre- sent season has exceeded that of any preceding
*The figures in this column represent only 90% of the market value of the exports, having been deducted by the Customs before leaving export duty.

year, especially in Upper Egypt. The climatic conditions during the early part of the season were very favorable and the crop promised to be a record one. Unfortunately in September and October much damage was done, more particularly in Upper Egypt, by the prevalence of "Boll worm," whose ravages this year were more pronounced than usual and far more in- jurious than those of the more generally feared "Cotton worm." During the season much valuable information regarding this pest has been obtained by the Khedivial Agricultural Society which it is hoped may subsequently be turned to practical account.
It is noteworthy that while the area devoted to cotton during recent years has steadily in- creased, there has been no increase in total crop production.

This is a matter for serious consideration, especially when taken in connection with the fact that quality also has left much to be desired. The tendency is now to grow cotton on the same land every two years, instead of once in three years, as was formerly the case, and the results of this system should not be ignor- red by the cultivator, not only because of possi- ble injury to the cotton-growing industry, which is in itself a sufficient reason, but also in view of its possible deleterious effects on the general productivity of the soil. The question of the seed employed is intimately connected with the qnuality of the resulting crop and is receiv- ing careful consideration by the Khedivial Agricultural Society. Prices continue to rule high.

div.head: REDUCTION OF TAXATION.
div.p: The following taxes are abolished or reduced with effect from the 1st January, 1906, (ex- cept the Customs duties reduced from the date of the Khedivial Decree of November 25th, 1905):-

Estimated Loss of revenue L.E. Salt Monopoly abolished ... ... 175,000 Tax on Sea-fishing boats ... ... 2,000 Ferry tax on canals abolished ... 7,000 Ferry tax on the Nile reduced... Red Sea lighthouse dues reduced... 30,000 Import duty reduced from 8% to 4% on coal, liquid fuel, char- coal, firewood, timber for build- ing purposes, petroleum; oxen, cows, sheep and goats, whether alive or cold-stored ... ... ... 118,000 L.S. 332,000

The Government Salt Monopoly established in 1879 for revenue purposes, was ceded in 1899 to the "Salt & Soda Company," when the price was reduced from L.E. 8 to L.E. 5 per ton. In a country like Egypt, in many parts of which salt is a natural product which anyone can pick up for himself, the existence of a monopoly with its accompanying restric- tions enforced by fines and imprisonment could not be other than highly vexatious, and in now sweeping it away the Khedivial Govern- ment has, it is believed, effected a reform which will be a blessing to the country at large and especially to the very poor.

The Salt and Soda Company was entitled to a six months’ notice of the termination of the Monopoly. This right it has consented to waive, while the Government on its side has engaged not to work any new salines, nor let them to others for a period of six years. Further the Company has undertaken to reduce the price of salt from L.E. 5 per ton to L.E. 2, (i. e. from 5 milliemes to 2 milliemes per kilo.) and to maintain distributing agencies wherever they now exist.
Licences for sea-fishing boats were formerly delivered on payment of an annual tax varying between L.E. 1 3/4 to L.E. 1O according to size and equipment. They will now be delivered free of charge.

The Perry Tax is abolished, except in the case of ferries at or near large centres. The tentative abolition of some of these latter was not a success, on the contrary it led to quarrels and disturbances on the part of rival claimants. Moreover it is necessary in places where there is heavy traffic that the public should have some guarantee of a satisfactory service, which can only be obtained by letting the ferrying right out to some responsible person.

The Lighthouse does in the Red Sea have been reduced from 14 milliemes to 10 mill. per ton for ships under 800 tons and from 7 milliemes to 5 milliemes for ships over that tonnage, reductions which it is hoped will prove satisfactory to international shipping.

An all-around ad valorem, Customs Duty on imports of 8 % constitutes the general tariff of the Turkish Empire, and consequently of Egypt, and no higher duty can be imposed except by International Agreement. In the case of Egypt a surtax exists on tobacco and tobacco only. For the first time, I believe, in history, a province of the Empire bound by this tariff, has, of its own initiative, lowered the import duty on a whole series of articles of first necessity. The experiment will be watched with interest not only in Egypt but throughout the world and it is the confident hope of the Khedive’s advisers that the reduc- tion, while it can hardly fail to benefit the consumer, will not, in the long run, prove detrimental to the Treasury.

As has already been stated, the Budget for 1906 includes a sum of no less than L.E. 120,000 for the improvement in the salaries of the Cadre officials, which for reasons given above have diminished in purchasing power to a distressing extent. In the case of the minor officials their pay no longer constitutes a living wage, and when vacancies occur no candidates are forthcoming to fill them. As the causes which produce this effect are precisely those that pour an increasing stream of wealth into the coffers of the State, it seemed but right that a portion of the same should be employed in ameliorating the lot of the Government servants. A good many salaries, especially of technical officials, have already been spasmodically rais- ed from time to time in order to retain the services of men who would otherwise have found it worth while to quit the Government service and even sacrifice their pension for the more lucrative prospects held out by private employers. It is now proposed to readjust the whole scale on a uniform basis. A Cadre Committee of experienced officials sat during the early months of the year and produced an interesting and careful report. The pressure of work which always occurs in the autumn has made it impossible to proceed further with the matter this year, but with the beginning of the new year it will be taken up again, and it is hoped that a month or two will suffice to rearrange the system on a sounder basis, such rearrangement to have effect from January 1st, 1906.

It is perhaps well that I should here men- tion that the sum of L. E. 120,000 set aside for this purpose, considerable as it is, will not, I fear, suffice to realise, the dreams of those who imagine that a golden age is approaching. It will be no more possible to amass a fortune in the Government service in the future than it was in the past. An equitable readjustment is all that is and can be aimed at, and I may add that efficient work and probably longer hours will be required in return for increas- ed pay.

In close connection with the reorganisation of the cadre is the question of a new Pension Law which is naow being taken seriously in hand under expert actuarial advice from Eng- land. The present law is admittedly had, but a scientific pension law in a country where the officials are partly Christian, partly native and partly foreign, presents enormous difficulties, and it is impossible to say when the project will be sufficiently advanced to be submitted to the Council of Ministers. Here, again, interested parties must not be too sanguine. It would be easy for the Khedive's present advisers to promulgate a pension law which would meet with popular favour. The results during the first ten years might be highly satisfactory; they would hardly be so much longer. In framing a pension lew it is necessary to calculate the cost not only for the present generation but for the next.

div.head: DAIRA SANIEH LIQUIDATION.
div.p: One of the most important financial events of the year was the liquidation of the Daira Administration, which was practically brought to an end in the course of 1905.
A summary of the question may not be uninteresting.

The settlement of the Financial situation of Egypt in November, 1876, took no account of the debt of the "Daira Sanieh," a special administration charged with the management of certain properties acquired by the late Khedive Ismail. With a view to paying off that debt an arrangement was made in 1877 by Messrs. Goschen & Joubert to float a loan having a first mortgage on the Daira Sanieh properties. The Khedivial Treasury engaged to make good any deficiency in the annual budget of the Daira Sanieh Administration after payment of the interest charge. The surplus revenue as well as the proceeds of sales, were assigned to the redemption of the debt.
Later on the Daira properties were ceded to the Government. The Law of Liquidation, in confirming the cession, maintained the same arrangement.
In 1890, the loan was converted, the balance of the debt standing at 7,299,860.

In 1898 the Government entered into an agreement with a group of financiers who undertook to realise the assets of the Daira, to pay off the balance of the debt, and to share the possible eventual profits equally with the Government. The venture turned out unex- pectedly successful for both parties.
Since 1898 all the properties of the Daira Sanieh have been sold, mostly to native land- owners, at a total price of about 12,100,000.

The excess of revenue of the Daira Adminis- tration, including that of 1905, amounted to nearly 1,200,000, making a grand total of 13,300,000. Deducting the loan outstanding in Hune 1898 viz; 6,431,000, the profit to be divided between the Government and the company, with some equitable deductions in favor of the latter, may be estimated at 6,800.
The balance of the loan still in circulation on the 15th October, 1905, viz., 4,444,340, has been paid off.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Mr. and Lady Victoria Machell left Mar- seilles on Friday by the Orient-Pacific liner Ortona for Egypt.
Prince and Princess Duleep Singh are also on the Ortona.
The Countess of Enniskillen has sailed from Marseilles for Egypt by the P. and O. Britannia.
The King has been pleased to approve of Baron von Humboldt-Dachroeden, late German Consul at Alexandria, as German Consul- General at Capetown for British South Africa.

We regret to inform our readers that the illness from which Sir Elwin Palmer is suffer- ing proves to be an attack of enteric fever, though the case is happily not regarded serious by the doctors. The utmost sympathy is felt for Sir Elwin Palmer prostrated by illness, in the middle of his work and the season, and for Lady Palmer, on whom must fall the burden of considerable anxiety and trouble.

We are glad to learn that Mr. Aspinall, the popular secretary of the Turf Club, Cairo, who has been laid up at Al Hayat, Helouan, with a severe attack of gout, is now making steady progress towards recovery. It will be some little time, however, before he will be fit to resume his duties.
Sir Charles Metcalfe has arrived from South Africa at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo.
H. H. Prince Ibrahim Pasha Halim and Herr von Mohl were among the passengers who arrived yesterday by the Austrian mail.

We regret to announce the death of Saleh Bay Heddeni, a member of the Alexandria Municipal Council, which took place on Sunday morning. Deceased was one of the mem- bers of the Alexandria Municipality nominated by the Government. The funeral took place yesterday.

The following passengers left for the Nile by the Nefertari on Friday: — Mr. A. Mee, Miss Mee, Mr. and Mrs. Kirkitirp, Shakir Bey Gazzel, Mme Shakir Gazzal, Miss Malvany, Miss E Malvany, Mr. and Mrs. Bollotte, Mr. Hay, Mr. Dyer, Miss F. A. Tayleur, Mr. and Mrs. Frank.

The following were the passengers by the P. S. Amenartas yesterday: —Dr and Mrs. Weleminsky, Mr. and Mrs. Howkins, Mr. L. Liebenthal, Miss E. Liebenthal, M. Thomas Inglis, Mr. Samuel Cohen, Mr. and Mrs. G. Watson, Mr. and Mrs. Heinrich Mayer.

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE
TRIBUNAL DE COMMERCE MIXTE
div.p: L’Affaire du "Cairo"
La tribunal Mixte de Commerce d’Alaxan- dria vient de prononcer son jugement dans l'affaire du “Cairo”.
En voici les principaux attendus.

Attendu que la Societe Generale de Navi- gation Italieone Florio Rubattino ayant fait abandon du navire et du fret, les demandeurs ont conolu a la nomination du Sieur Prencipi deja nomme tiers consiguataire du navire “Cairo” par ordonnance du nrefere du 21 mars 1905, liquidateur judiciaire pour la repartition amiable entre parties sauf a porter toute con- testation devant ce tribunal; quils demandent en meme temps la fixation du montant du pejudice materiel et moral subi par suite du nanfrage;

Attendu que la Societe Florio Rubattino declare que par suite de l’abandon elle n’a pas de conclusions a prendre du chef de la liquidation des sommes reclamees a titre de dommages-interets et qu'elle adhere-a la nomi- nation du liquidateur judiciaire dans les termes de la demande ; qu’il y a lieu de lui donner acte de cette declaration.
Attendu que le Comire des assureurs mari- time de Genes tout en contestant les dom- mages moraux declare s’eu referer a justice pour le reste ;

Attendu en ce qui concerne les dommages- interets que les demandeurs font valoir le prejudice materiel resultant de la perte d leurs effets et le prejudice moral a eux cause par les angoisses et souffrances eprouvees pendant le naufrage; qu’en l’espece l-element moral etant de nature imponderable et par suits non susceptible d’etre apprecie en argent le tribunal estime qu'il n’y a pas lieu de prendre en consideration le pretendu prejudice moral et se borne a l'evaluation du prejudice materiel ;

Attendu que le serment “in litem" propose par une partie des demandeurs n’est pas admissible, un tel serment n’etant prevu par auoun article du Code de Procedure ; que les demandes paraissant pour la plupart etre exagerees, le tribunal en tenant compte de la situation respective des demandeurs dout une partie formait une troupe d’artistes dramatiques et les autres etaient passagers de 3me classe, pour la majeure partie de profession inconnue et apres avoir procede a une reduction taut proportionnelle que progressive a fixe ex sequo et bono les sommes plus bas indiquees en estimant qu'elles cons- tituaieut une auffisante reparation.

Par ces motifs:
Statuant publiquement et contradictoire- ment, le Ministere Public entendu, ecartant toutes conclusions plus amples ou contraires; joint les affaires insorites au Role General sub N' 3036 jusqu’a 3034, 3056, 3058, 5295 jusqu’a 5324 de la XXXeme annee et statuant par un seal et meme jugement;
Donne acte aux Sieurs Edward L. Lawrence, De Blauche L. Lawrence, De Vve Elizabeth C. Whiting, Sieur von Alten, Dr Hugo Wernicke de leur intervention ;

Donne acte a la Societe Generale de Na- vigation Italienne Florio Rubattino qu’elle n'a pas de conclusions a prendre sur la liqui- dation des creances des demandeurs du chef de la perte de leurs effets ou dommages moraux et qu’elle adhere a la nomination d’un liquida- teur dans les conditions de la demande;
Nomme sur accord des parties le Sieur A. Prencipe liquidateur judiciaire pour la reparti- tion du net produit du navire echoue “Cairo" et du fret abandonne;

Liquide les creances des demandeurs et des intervenants von Alten et Wernicke en les re- duisant aux sommes suivantes... (suit une liste complete et detaillee des demandeurs avec le montant de leurs indemnites respec- tives).

Renvoie led parties a faire compte devant le liquidateur; dit que faute d’entente amiable entre parties sur toute question relative a la repartition notamment en ce qni concerne la determination du fret abandonne, les frais du sauvetage et les droits eventuels de privilege ou de preference entre passagers et chargeurs, les contestations seront portees devant ce tribunal pour y etre statue ulte- rieurement sur requete de la partie la plus diligente.
Depens a la charge de la liquidation.

Le President
(Signe De Zoltan.
Ce jugement accorde a Ermete Novelli une somme de 75000 francs et a Olga Giannini une autre somme de 40000 francs. Le total general des indemnites est d’environ 200,000 francs.

div.head: ORDRB DU JOUR DE LA COMMISSION.
div.p: Une seance de la Commission Municipale aura lieu mercredi 27 Decembre 1905, a 4 h. p.m. au palais municipal avec l’ordre du jour suivant:

1.—Budget de 1906. 2.—Rapport du Comite des Plantations sur la projet des parcs et jardins. 3.—Interpellation de Monsieur Zouro sur diverses questions. 4.—Proposition de principe tendent a la construction d’un destructeur d'immondices. 5.—Excedents et emprises, suivant etats de la Delegation des 21 Novembre et 12 Decembre 1905 aunsi que expropriations pour l'overture de la rue allant de la rue Metualli a la rue de la Marine et pour l‘establissement d’une place sur la necropole d’Anfouchy. 6.-Communications diverses.

div.head: LES HABITATIONS ECONOMIQUES
div.p: On nous communique la traduction suivante d'un article du Messagiere Egiziano :

C'est avec une reelle satisfaction et un ferme espoir de reussite que le public de notre ville a appris qua la Municipalite a pris en serieuse consideration le projet des "habitations eco- nomiques" presente par la Commission Inter- nationale des Locataires, at a, seance tenante, afin de mieux etudier, apprecier et resoudre la question vitale des loyers, nomme un Comite special compose de MM. Fenderl, Mansour Bey Youssef, Zervudachi et Chataway Bey.

Ce faisant, la Municipalite d’Alexandrie, consciente des justes plaintss qui a’elevent journellement de la blasse ouvriere-cette derniere est celle, en effet, qui se ressant le plus des augmentations tonjours croissantes des loyers—vient d’accomplir, par sa louable determination, une ceuvre hautement huma- nitaire, qui lui vaudra non seulement la reconnaissance de la population ouvriere de la ville, mais encore la satisfaction d'avoir soulage un nombre considerable de families qui souvent sont obligees de se priver de manger pour pouvoir arriver a payer leur terme.

Nous vivona dans nn siflole ot le progrts est a l’ordre du jour, et necessite pour l’homme une juste recompense de ses fatigues. Il doit, sans exiger le superflu, avoir le necessaire, afin de demeurer sain et robuste, actif et laborieux et par suite honnete et bon.
Il existe ici des personnes, qui ne manquent ni de coeur ni d’intelligence, et qui n’etant pas egoistes, out compris que le pays a le droit d’evoluer vers le progres et la civilisation.

Les membres dont se compose le Comite d’etude nomme parsla Commission sont plei- nement a la hauteur de la mission qui leur a ete confiee, et c'est-plains d’espoir dans leur reussite que nous attendons avec impatience le jour ou la villa entiere se fera un devoir de remercier publiquement les personnes qui auront participe a un tel relevement econo- mique.

Vous, donc, Messieurs, qui avez ete choisis pour resoudre une question sur et pour le bien general, nos voeux les plus sinceres vous accompagnent. Accomplissez votre haute mis- siou de facon a ce qu’on puisse, dans la suite, vons citer comme example de conseillers honnetes, capables et philanthropiques.

Avant de terminer, permettez moi, a titre de reconnaissance, de remercier chaudement cha- que membre en particulier de la Commission des Locataires. Sans etre rebutes par les fatiques, les desillusions, affrontant toutes especes de difficultes, et confiants dans leurs bonnes actions et leur devoir ils ont su lutter avec une energie indomptable, contre tous ceux qui s’opposerent a leurs desseins, mon- trant a cette classe ouvriere et laborieuse, dont ils avaient assume la defense, qu’ils etaient toujours la pour proteger ses interets vitaux.
Sans a’attarder aux mesquines insinuations qui ont ete faites a ce sujet, la louable deci- sion de la Municipalite y a mis un terme et c’est avec impatience que le public eu attend le resultat.

div.head: Societe Anonyme des Eaux du Caire
AVIS
div.p: II est porte a la connaissance du public que le Conseil d’Administration de la a de- cide de reduire de 22 % le prix de l’eau fournie aux Bornes-fontaines publiques.
En consequence, a partir du ler Janvier 1906 on pourra obtenir l’eau aux dites fontai- nes a raison de P. T. 3 (trois piastres tarif) le metre cube au lieu de P.T. 3,857 payees jus- qu’ici.

Cette reduction de prix ayant ete decidee par la Societe dans le seul but d’en faire profiter les habitants de la Ville, le public est prie da veiller a ce que la dite reduction lui soit faite par les sakas qui lui fouraissent l’eau, afiu de ne pas laisser ces derniers profiter du rabais qui n’a ete consenti qu’en faveur du public.
La vente d’eau au detail aux. Bornes-fontai nes, s’etablit done comme suit:

Le tonneau de 660 kilos de jauge 20 milliemes La guerbe de 66 ,, „ 2 „ L’eatagnon de 28 „ „ 3/4 „ et pour toute quantite depassant la jauge ci- dessus, chaque 4 kilos seront comptes a 1/8 de milliemes. Le Caire, le 19 Decembre 1905. Le Directeur Astley F Friend

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIE
AVIS
div.p: La Municipalite met en adjudication la four- niture de diverse articles pour le Service du Nettoiement pour l’exercice 1906.
Le cautionnement est fixe a 15 % de l’offre.
Le cahier des charges est depose an Bureau de Nettoiement ou il peut etre consulte par les interesses tous les jours de 9 h. a midi, les jours leries exceptes.
Les offres devrout etre addressees sous pli cachete a Monsieur l’Administrateur de la Municipalite avant le 16 Janvier 1906.
Eues pourront egalement etre deposees en seance de la Delegation le meme jour a 5 h. p.m.
L’enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour tourniture de divers srticles pour Service du Nettoiement.

Le cautionuement ou le recu d'une banque, d'apres les conditions du cahier des charges, devra etre remis separement au Service de la Comptabilite Generals avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 16 Janvier 1905 a midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera ecartee.
L'Administrateur (Signe) E.P. CHATAWAY Alexandrie, le 20 Decembre 1905.
AVIS

Le Mercredi 27 Decembre courant de 3 a 5 h. p.m. la Municipalite procedera a la vente aux encheres publiques dans ses sepots de la rue du ler Khedive d'une quantite derm3. 44 environ de moelions divisee en lota de 40 a 100 m3.

Les acheteurs devront payer la droit d'en cheres de 1% et deposer le 10% de la valeur de la marchandise achetee au moment de la vente et effectuer le paiement integral a la Caissee Municipale le lendemain du jour de l'adjudication.
Ils auront a supporter les droits de carriere a profit de la Ville et devrout eulever les pierres achetees dans un delai dedix jours sous peine de folle enchere pour compte de l'adjudicataire.
L'Administrateur (Signe) E.P. CHATAWAY Alexandrie, le 19 Decembre 1905.
